title: E-commerce Reverse Logistics Optimization
content: An online retailer operates from multiple regional warehouses (`<loc_depot>`) to manage both deliveries and returns. Each delivery truck (capacity `<capacity>`) must visit `<num_customer>` customer locations (`<loc_customer>`) to drop off ordered items (`<demand_linehaul>`) and collect returned products (`<demand_backhaul>`). Time windows (`<time_windows>`) are set for each customer visit to align with their availability. The goal is to design routes that efficiently balance deliveries and pickups without overloading trucks, while minimizing total distance and respecting service schedules.

title: Waste Collection and Recycling Route Planning
content: A municipal waste management company uses `<loc_depot>` depots to manage trash collection and recycling pickup. Trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) must service `<num_customer>` residential/commercial sites (`<loc_customer>`), where `<demand_linehaul>` represents trash volume and `<demand_backhaul>` denotes recyclables. Time windows (`<time_windows>`) are enforced to ensure access during specified hours (e.g., mornings only). Routes must account for mixed backhauls—collecting trash first or recyclables first—while avoiding capacity overflow and optimizing fuel use across depots.

title: Event Equipment Delivery and Rental Returns
content: A rental company supplies equipment to event venues (`<loc_customer>`) from `<loc_depot>` warehouses. Trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) deliver gear (`<demand_linehaul>`, e.g., chairs, generators) and later collect returned items (`<demand_backhaul>`). title: Pharmacy Prescription Delivery and Medication Retrieval
content: A chain of pharmacies (`<loc_depot>`) delivers prescriptions (`<demand_linehaul>`) to patients and retrieves expired medications (`<demand_backhaul>`). Delivery teams must visit `<num_customer>` homes (`<loc_customer>`) within personalized time windows (`<time_windows>`) to accommodate patient schedules. title: Farm Supply Delivery and Crop Harvest Collection
content: An agricultural cooperative uses `<loc_depot>` hubs to distribute farming supplies (`<demand_linehaul>`, e.g., seeds, fertilizers) to `<num_customer>` farms (`<loc_customer>`) and collect harvested crops (`<demand_backhaul>`). Time windows (`<time_windows>`) are critical for crop pickups, as delays risk spoilage. Trucks (capacity `<capacity>`) must plan routes across depots, prioritize deliveries before harvest pickups where necessary, and avoid exceeding load limits while serving remote rural locations efficiently.

title: Hospital Supply Delivery and Medical Waste Collection
content: Healthcare logistics providers must manage multiple depots (e.g., medical warehouses and waste treatment facilities) to deliver critical supplies like IV fluids and surgical kits to hospitals while collecting biohazardous waste for disposal. Each vehicle’s capacity (C) must balance outgoing medical supplies and incoming waste. Time windows (TW) ensure urgent deliveries align with hospital shift schedules, while pickups occur during facility downtime. Mixed backhauls (MB) allow flexible routing, such as dropping off supplies first and then collecting waste, provided the combined load stays within capacity limits.

title: Automotive Parts Delivery and Recycling Pickup
content: An automotive supplier operates from multiple depots (MD), including part distribution hubs and metal recycling centers. Trucks (C) must transport new engine components to repair shops while retrieving scrap metal for recycling. Time windows (TW) prioritize rush-hour deliveries for urgent repairs, while pickups are scheduled during off-peak hours. Mixed backhauls (MB) let drivers optimize routes by interweaving deliveries and pickups, ensuring scrap metal doesn’t overload the vehicle before dropping off parts.

title: Construction Material Delivery and Waste Recycling Collection
content: Construction firms require timely delivery of raw materials (e.g., concrete, lumber) to job sites and removal of debris for recycling. Time windows (TW) align with construction crews’ schedules, and mixed backhauls (MB) let drivers first drop off materials at morning sites and collect waste during afternoon rounds, avoiding overloading.

title: School Meal Delivery and Empty Container Return
content: A school meal provider uses multiple depots (MD) to distribute prepacked lunches to schools and collect reusable containers afterward. Mixed backhauls (MB) let drivers return containers to central kitchens during afternoon routes, optimizing routes to minimize idle time between deliveries and collections.

title: Retail Inventory Replenishment and Returns Handling
content: A retail chain’s logistics team operates from multiple distribution centers (MD) to restock stores with new merchandise while collecting returned items for redistribution or disposal. Time windows (TW) match store operating hours, and mixed backhauls (MB) allow drivers to drop off new stock in the morning and collect returns in the afternoon, ensuring neither exceeds capacity limits.

content: An international cargo company operates from multiple regional hubs (<loc_depot>) to manage time-sensitive deliveries and returns for global shipments.
